title: Case Study 12: Reilly Rinne
chief_complaint: Mother reports noticing occasional drainage from the right ear and recently noticed that his attention/hearing seemed to fluctuate.

problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral history, current concerns Right ear
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Follow-up check on PE tubes status

history.present_illness: Patient is seen for follow-up 2 months after bilateral PE tube insertion. Pre-operative status showed bilateral moderate conductive loss which improved to near normal post-operatively. Recently, mother noticed right ear drainage and fluctuating hearing.
history.otologic_history: Bilateral PE tube insertion 2 months ago.
history.medical_psych_history: Speech and language seem age appropriate.
history.patient_goals: Evaluate tube function and hearing status.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear shows normal equivalent volume (0.7) with no measurable peak (NP), suggesting a blocked tube or fluid with intact eardrum. Left ear shows large equivalent volume (3.9) with no peak, consistent with a patent PE tube.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear demonstrates a mild-to-moderate hearing loss (PTA 35 dB HL). Left ear thresholds are within normal limits (PTA 10 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs align with PTAs. Word recognition is excellent (100%) bilaterally, though the right ear required higher presentation levels. Testing performed with familiar spondees and PBK-word list.

overall_audiologic_summary: Evaluation reveals asymmetric hearing sensitivity. The left ear presents with normal hearing and tympanometric findings consistent with a patent (open) PE tube. The right ear shows a mild-to-moderate hearing loss with tympanometric findings (normal volume, flat trace) consistent with a blocked PE tube and likely recurrence of middle ear effusion/infection, correlating with the reported drainage.
counseling_points: The tube in the left ear is open and working well; hearing on that side is normal.
The tube in the right ear appears to be blocked (not working), which explains the drainage and the return of some hearing loss.
The hearing loss in the right ear is temporary and related to the fluid/infection.
We will refer you back to the ENT physician to manage the drainage and check the right tube.
notes_for_actor: Mother should appear concerned about the drainage but relieved that the left ear is still hearing well.
Patient (Reilly) is 4 years old; if portrayed, may be playful but potentially fussy if the right ear is uncomfortable.
